author_blurb.en: Translated for SuttaCentral by Bhikkhu Sujato, 2018. Dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation in any way you wish. Attribution is appreciated but not legally required.

segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 22
segments.en: Linked Discourses 22

segments.pli: 9. Theravagga
segments.en: 9. Senior Mendicants

segments.pli: 89. Khemakasutta
segments.en: 89. With Khemaka

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā therā bhikkhū kosambiyaṃ viharanti ghositārāme.
segments.en: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā khemako badarikārāme viharati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
segments.en: Now at that time Venerable Khemaka was staying in the Jujube Tree Monastery, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

segments.pli: Atha kho therā bhikkhū sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitā āyasmantaṃ dāsakaṃ āmantesuṃ:
segments.en: In the late afternoon those senior mendicants came out of retreat and addressed Venerable Dāsaka,

segments.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, āvuso dāsaka, yena khemako bhikkhu tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā khemakaṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadehi:
segments.en: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:

segments.pli: ‘therā taṃ, āvuso khemaka, evamāhaṃsu—
segments.en: ‘Reverend Khemaka, the seniors

segments.pli: kacci te, āvuso, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti no abhikkamanti, paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no abhikkamo’”ti?
segments.en: hope you’re keeping well; they hope you’re alright. They hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.’”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā dāsako therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭissutvā yenāyasmā khemako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ khemakaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He went to Khemaka and said to him:

segments.pli: “therā taṃ, āvuso khemaka, evamāhaṃsu:
segments.en: “Reverend Khemaka, the seniors

segments.pli: ‘kacci te, āvuso, khamanīyaṃ … pe … no abhikkamo’”ti?
segments.en: hope you’re keeping well; they hope you’re alright. They hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

segments.pli: “Na me, āvuso, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ … pe … abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no paṭikkamo”ti.
segments.en: “Reverend, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dāsako yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Dāsaka went to those seniors and told them what had happened. They said,

segments.pli: “khemako, āvuso, bhikkhu evamāha:
‘na me, āvuso, khamanīyaṃ … pe … abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no paṭikkamo’”ti.
“Ehi tvaṃ, āvuso dāsaka, yena khemako bhikkhu tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā khemakaṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadehi:
segments.en: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:

segments.pli: ‘therā taṃ, āvuso khemaka, evamāhaṃsu—
segments.en: ‘Reverend Khemaka, the seniors say that

segments.pli: pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: these five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:

segments.pli: rūpupādānakkhandho, vedanupādānakkhandho, saññupādānakkhandho, saṅkhārupādānakkhandho, viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
segments.en: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

segments.pli: Imesu āyasmā khemako pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassatī’”ti?
segments.en: Do you regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self?’”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā dāsako therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭissutvā yenāyasmā khemako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā … pe …
segments.en: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:

segments.pli: therā taṃ, āvuso khemaka, evamāhaṃsu:
“pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—
rūpupādānakkhandho … pe … viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
Imesu āyasmā khemako pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassatī”ti?
“Pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: “These five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:

segments.pli: rūpupādānakkhandho … pe … viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
segments.en: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

segments.pli: Imesu khvāhaṃ, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu na kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassāmī”ti.
segments.en: I do not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dāsako yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Dāsaka went to those seniors and told them what had happened. They said:

segments.pli: “khemako, āvuso, bhikkhu evamāha:
‘pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—
rūpupādānakkhandho … pe … viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
Imesu khvāhaṃ, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu na kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassāmī’”ti.
“Ehi tvaṃ, āvuso dāsaka, yena khemako bhikkhu tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā khemakaṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadehi:
segments.en: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:

segments.pli: ‘therā taṃ, āvuso khemaka, evamāhaṃsu—
segments.en: ‘Reverend Khemaka, the seniors say that

segments.pli: pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: these five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:

segments.pli: rūpupādānakkhandho … pe … viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
segments.en: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

segments.pli: No ce kirāyasmā khemako imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassati.
segments.en: If, as it seems, Venerable Khemaka does not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self,

segments.pli: Tenahāyasmā khemako arahaṃ khīṇāsavo’”ti.
segments.en: then he is a perfected one, with defilements ended.’”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā dāsako therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭissutvā yenāyasmā khemako … pe …
segments.en: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:

segments.pli: therā taṃ, āvuso khemaka, evamāhaṃsu:
“pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—
rūpupādānakkhandho … pe … viññāṇupādānakkhandho;
no ce kirāyasmā khemako imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassati, tenahāyasmā khemako arahaṃ khīṇāsavo”ti.
“Pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: “These five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:

segments.pli: rūpupādānakkhandho … pe … viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
segments.en: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

segments.pli: Imesu khvāhaṃ, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu na kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassāmi, na camhi arahaṃ khīṇāsavo;
segments.en: I do not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self, yet I am not a perfected one, with defilements ended.

segments.pli: api ca me, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu ‘asmī’ti adhigataṃ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti na ca samanupassāmī”ti.
segments.en: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the conceit ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dāsako yena therā bhikkhū … pe …
segments.en: Then Dāsaka went to those seniors and told them what had happened. They said:

segments.pli: there bhikkhū etadavoca:
“khemako, āvuso, bhikkhu evamāha—
pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—
rūpupādānakkhandho … pe … viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
Imesu khvāhaṃ, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu na kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassāmi, na camhi arahaṃ khīṇāsavo;
api ca me, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu ‘asmī’ti adhigataṃ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti na ca samanupassāmī”ti.
“Ehi tvaṃ, āvuso dāsaka, yena khemako bhikkhu tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā khemakaṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadehi:
segments.en: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:

segments.pli: ‘therā taṃ, āvuso khemaka, evamāhaṃsu—
segments.en: ‘Reverend Khemaka, the seniors ask,

segments.pli: yametaṃ, āvuso khemaka, asmīti vadesi, kimetaṃ asmīti vadesi?
segments.en: when you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?

segments.pli: Rūpaṃ asmīti vadesi, aññatra rūpā asmīti vadesi,
segments.en: Is it form or apart from form?

segments.pli: vedanaṃ …
segments.en: Is it feeling …

segments.pli: saññaṃ …
segments.en: perception …

segments.pli: saṅkhāre …
segments.en: choices …

segments.pli: viññāṇaṃ asmīti vadesi, aññatra viññāṇā asmīti vadesi.
segments.en: consciousness, or apart from consciousness?

segments.pli: Yametaṃ, āvuso khemaka, asmīti vadesi. Kimetaṃ asmīti vadesī’”ti?
segments.en: When you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā dāsako therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭissutvā yenāyasmā khemako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ khemakaṃ etadavoca—
segments.en: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:

segments.pli: therā taṃ, āvuso khemaka, evamāhaṃsu:
“yametaṃ, āvuso khemaka, ‘asmī’ti vadesi, kimetaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadesi?
Rūpaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadesi aññatra rūpā ‘asmī’ti vadesi?
Vedanaṃ …
saññaṃ …
saṅkhāre …
viññāṇaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadesi aññatra viññāṇā ‘asmī’ti vadesi?
Yametaṃ, āvuso khemaka, ‘asmī’ti vadesi, kimetaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadesī”ti?
“Alaṃ, āvuso dāsaka, kiṃ imāya sandhāvanikāya.
segments.en: “Enough, Reverend Dāsaka! What’s the point in running back and forth?

segments.pli: Āharāvuso, daṇḍaṃ;
segments.en: Bring my staff,

segments.pli: ahameva yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkamissāmī”ti.
segments.en: I’ll go to see the senior mendicants myself.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā khemako daṇḍamolubbha yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā therehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ sammodi.
segments.en: Then Venerable Khemaka, leaning on a staff, went to those senior mendicants and exchanged greetings with them.

segments.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ khemakaṃ therā bhikkhū etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. They said to him:

segments.pli: “yametaṃ, āvuso khemaka, ‘asmī’ti vadesi, kimetaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadesi?
segments.en: “Reverend Khemaka, when you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?

segments.pli: Rūpaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadesi, aññatra rūpā ‘asmī’ti vadesi?
segments.en: Is it form or apart from form?

segments.pli: Vedanaṃ …
segments.en: Is it feeling …

segments.pli: saññaṃ …
segments.en: perception …

segments.pli: saṅkhāre …
segments.en: choices …

segments.pli: viññāṇaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadesi, aññatra viññāṇā ‘asmī’ti vadesi?
segments.en: consciousness, or apart from consciousness?

segments.pli: Yametaṃ, āvuso khemaka, ‘asmī’ti vadesi, kimetaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadesī”ti?
segments.en: When you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?”

segments.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ, āvuso, rūpaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadāmi; napi aññatra rūpā ‘asmī’ti vadāmi.
segments.en: “Reverends, I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to form, or apart from form.

segments.pli: Na vedanaṃ …
segments.en: I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to feeling …

segments.pli: na saññaṃ …
segments.en: perception …

segments.pli: na saṅkhāre …
segments.en: choices …

segments.pli: na viññāṇaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadāmi; napi aññatra viññāṇā ‘asmī’ti vadāmi.
segments.en: consciousness, or apart from consciousness.

segments.pli: Api ca me, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu ‘asmī’ti adhigataṃ ‘ayamahamasmī’ti na ca samanupassāmi.
segments.en: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the conceit ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, uppalassa vā padumassa vā puṇḍarīkassa vā gandho.
segments.en: It’s like the scent of a blue water lily, or a pink or white lotus.

segments.pli: Yo nu kho evaṃ vadeyya: ‘pattassa gandho’ti vā ‘vaṇṇassa gandho’ti vā ‘kiñjakkhassa gandho’ti vā sammā nu kho so vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
segments.en: Would it be right to say that the scent belongs to the petals or the stalk or the pistil?”

segments.pli: “No hetaṃ, āvuso”.
segments.en: “No, reverend.”

segments.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ, panāvuso, sammā byākaramāno byākareyyā”ti?
segments.en: “Then, reverends, how should it be said?”

segments.pli: “‘Pupphassa gandho’ti kho, āvuso, sammā byākaramāno byākareyyā”ti.
segments.en: “It would be right to say that the scent belongs to the flower.”

segments.pli: “Evameva khvāhaṃ, āvuso, na rūpaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadāmi, napi aññatra rūpā ‘asmī’ti vadāmi.
segments.en: “In the same way, reverends, I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to form, or apart from form.

segments.pli: Na vedanaṃ …
segments.en: I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to feeling …

segments.pli: na saññaṃ …
segments.en: perception …

segments.pli: na saṅkhāre …
segments.en: choices …

segments.pli: na viññāṇaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadāmi, napi aññatra viññāṇā ‘asmī’ti vadāmi.
segments.en: consciousness, or apart from consciousness.

segments.pli: Api ca me, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu ‘asmī’ti adhigataṃ ‘ayamahamasmī’ti na ca samanupassāmi.
segments.en: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the conceit ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.

segments.pli: Kiñcāpi, āvuso, ariyasāvakassa pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni pahīnāni bhavanti, atha khvassa hoti: ‘yo ca pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu anusahagato asmīti māno, asmīti chando, asmīti anusayo asamūhato.
segments.en: Although a noble disciple has given up the five lower fetters, they still have a lingering residue of the conceit ‘I am’, the desire ‘I am’, and the underlying tendency ‘I am’ which has not been eradicated.

segments.pli: So aparena samayena pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassī viharati—
segments.en: After some time they meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.

segments.pli: iti rūpaṃ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
segments.en: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

segments.pli: iti vedanā …
segments.en: Such is feeling …

segments.pli: iti saññā …
segments.en: Such is perception …

segments.pli: iti saṅkhārā …
segments.en: Such are choices …

segments.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti.
segments.en: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

segments.pli: Tassimesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassino viharato yopissa hoti pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu anusahagato ‘asmī’ti, māno ‘asmī’ti, chando ‘asmī’ti anusayo asamūhato, sopi samugghātaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: As they do so, that lingering residue is eradicated.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, vatthaṃ saṃkiliṭṭhaṃ malaggahitaṃ. Tamenaṃ sāmikā rajakassa anupadajjuṃ.
segments.en: Suppose there was a cloth that was dirty and soiled, so the owners give it to a launderer.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ rajako ūse vā khāre vā gomaye vā sammadditvā acche udake vikkhāleti.
segments.en: The launderer kneads it thoroughly with salt, lye, and cow dung, and rinses it in clear water.

segments.pli: Kiñcāpi taṃ hoti vatthaṃ parisuddhaṃ pariyodātaṃ, atha khvassa hoti yeva anusahagato ūsagandho vā khāragandho vā gomayagandho vā asamūhato.
segments.en: Although that cloth is clean and bright, it still has a lingering scent of salt, lye, or cow dung that had not been eradicated.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ rajako sāmikānaṃ deti. Tamenaṃ sāmikā gandhaparibhāvite karaṇḍake nikkhipanti.
segments.en: The launderer returns it to its owners, who store it in a chest permeated with scent.

segments.pli: Yopissa hoti anusahagato ūsagandho vā khāragandho vā gomayagandho vā asamūhato, sopi samugghātaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: And that lingering scent would be eradicated.

segments.pli: Evameva kho, āvuso, kiñcāpi ariyasāvakassa pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni pahīnāni bhavanti, atha khvassa hoti yeva pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu anusahagato ‘asmī’ti, māno ‘asmī’ti, chando ‘asmī’ti anusayo asamūhato.
segments.en: In the same way, although a noble disciple has given up the five lower fetters, they still have a lingering residue of the conceit ‘I am’, the desire ‘I am’, and the underlying tendency ‘I am’ which has not been eradicated.

segments.pli: So aparena samayena pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassī viharati.
segments.en: After some time they meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.

segments.pli: ‘Iti rūpaṃ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
segments.en: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

segments.pli: iti vedanā …
segments.en: Such is feeling …

segments.pli: iti saññā …
segments.en: Such is perception …

segments.pli: iti saṅkhārā …
segments.en: Such are choices …

segments.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti.
segments.en: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

segments.pli: Tassa imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassino viharato yopissa hoti pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu anusahagato ‘asmī’ti, māno ‘asmī’ti, chando ‘asmī’ti anusayo asamūhato, sopi samugghātaṃ gacchatī”ti.
segments.en: As they do so, that lingering residue is eradicated.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, therā bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ khemakaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: When he said this, the senior mendicants said to Venerable Khemaka,

segments.pli: “na kho mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ khemakaṃ vihesāpekhā pucchimha, api cāyasmā khemako pahosi tassa bhagavato sāsanaṃ vitthārena ācikkhituṃ desetuṃ paññāpetuṃ paṭṭhapetuṃ vivarituṃ vibhajituṃ uttānīkātuṃ.
segments.en: “We didn’t want to trouble Venerable Khemaka with our questions. But you’re capable of explaining, teaching, advocating, establishing, disclosing, analyzing, and clarifying the Buddha’s instructions in detail.

segments.pli: Tayidaṃ āyasmatā khemakena tassa bhagavato sāsanaṃ vitthārena ācikkhitaṃ desitaṃ paññāpitaṃ paṭṭhapitaṃ vivaritaṃ vibhajitaṃ uttānīkatan”ti.
segments.en: And that’s just what you’ve done.”

segments.pli: Idamavoca āyasmā khemako.
segments.en: That’s what Venerable Khemaka said.

segments.pli: Attamanā therā bhikkhū āyasmato khemakassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanduṃ.
segments.en: Satisfied, the senior mendicants were happy with what Venerable Khemaka said.

segments.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne saṭṭhimattānaṃ therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsu, āyasmato khemakassa cāti.
segments.en: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty senior mendicants and of Venerable Khemaka were freed from defilements by not grasping.

segments.pli: Sattamaṃ.

sections.title: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near…

suttaplex.blurb: Venerable Khemaka is ill, and some senior mendicants ask Dāsaka to convey their concern to him. There follows a series of exchanges mediated by Dāsaka until eventually Khemaka, despite his illness, goes to see the other mendicants himself. The seniors are asking to determine Khemaka’s understanding of the Dhamma, and he says that although he has let go of the five lower fetters, he still has a residual attachment to the five aggregates.
